title: Chillisquaque Creek
text:
Chillisquaque Creek is a <a href="tributary">tributary</a> of the <a href="West%20Branch%20Susquehanna%20River">West Branch Susquehanna River</a> in <a href="Montour%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Montour County</a> and <a href="Northumberland%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Northumberland County</a>, in <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, in the United States. It is approximately long and flows through <a href="Derry%20Township%2C%20Montour%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Derry Township</a>, <a href="Washingtonville%2C%20Pennsylvania">Washingtonville</a>, and <a href="Liberty%20Township%2C%20Montour%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Liberty Township</a> in Montour County and <a href="East%20Chillisquaque%20Township%2C%20Northumberland%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">East Chillisquaque Township</a> and <a href="West%20Chillisquaque%20Township%2C%20Northumberland%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">West Chillisquaque Township</a> in Northumberland County. The watershed of the creek has an area of . Agricultural impacts have caused most of the streams in the watershed of the creek (including the <a href="main%20stem">main stem</a>) to be impaired. Causes of impairment include sedimentation/siltation and habitat alteration. The average annual discharge of the creek between 1980 and 2014 ranged from . Its watershed mainly consists of rolling agricultural land. The creek's channel flows through rock formations consisting of sandstone and shale. It is a warmwater stream.
The watershed of Chillisquaque Creek occupies parts of four counties: Columbia County, Montour County, Northumberland County, and Lycoming County. There is a gauging station along the creek near Washingtonville. A Shawnee village had been established at the confluence with the West Branch Susquehanna River by 1728. A fort known as <a href="Fort%20Bosley">Fort Bosley</a> also historically existed on the creek near Washingtonville. Numerous bridges were built over the creek in the 19th and 20th centuries, two of which are on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>. The creek is designated as a Warmwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery. It lacks trout, but has in the past been stocked with various other fish species. A tract of the creek's floodplain is known as the Chillisquaque Creek Natural Area and is owned by <a href="Bucknell%20University">Bucknell University</a>. Various bird species have been observed near it and woodland wildflowers inhabit the creek's vicinity. Recreational opportunities in the watershed include canoeing and fishing.
Course.
Chillisquaque Creek begins at the confluence of <a href="East%20Branch%20Chillisquaque%20Creek">East Branch Chillisquaque Creek</a> and <a href="Middle%20Branch%20Chillisquaque%20Creek">Middle Branch Chillisquaque Creek</a> near the northern border of Derry Township, Montour County. It flows west-southwest for a few tenths of a mile before turning south-southwest. After several tenths of a mile, it turns west for a short distance and receives the tributary <a href="West%20Branch%20Chillisquaque%20Creek">West Branch Chillisquaque Creek</a> from the <a href="wikt%3Aright%20bank">right</a>. The creek then turns south-southeast for more than a mile, flowing alongside <a href="Pennsylvania%20Route%2054">Pennsylvania Route 54</a> and crossing it once. In this reach, it briefly flows alongside the western border of Washingtonville before crossing <a href="Pennsylvania%20Route%20254">Pennsylvania Route 254</a> and receiving the tributary <a href="Mud%20Creek%20%28Chillisquaque%20Creek%29">Mud Creek</a> from the <a href="wikt%3Aleft%20bank">left</a>. The creek then begins flowing in a roughly west-southwesterly direction and soon enters Liberty Township. It continues flowing in a similar direction in Liberty Township (though it does flow north, west, and then south for several tenths of a mile at one point), flowing through a broad valley with <a href="Limestone%20Ridge">Limestone Ridge</a> on the north and receiving many unnamed tributaries from both sides. After several miles, the creek leaves the valley and crosses <a href="Interstate%2080">Interstate 80</a>. Several tenths of a mile further downstream, it exits Liberty Township and Montour County.
Upon exiting Montour County, Chillisquaque Creek enters East Chillisquaque Township, Northumberland County. It then turns south-southeast for about a mile, flowing close to the county line and crossing <a href="Pennsylvania%20Route%20642">Pennsylvania Route 642</a>. In this reach, it receives <a href="Beaver%20Run%20%28Chillisquaque%20Creek%29">Beaver Run</a>, its last named tributary, from the left. The creek then turns southwest for a few tenths of a mile before turning south for a similar distance. It then turns west for several tenths of a mile before turning southwest. The creek crosses <a href="Pennsylvania%20Route%2045">Pennsylvania Route 45</a> and meanders in a southwesterly direction for more than a mile, flowing along the border between East Chillisquaque Township and West Chillisquaque Township. It then turns south for a few tenths of a mile, passing the <a href="Rishel%20Covered%20Bridge">Rishel Covered Bridge</a> as it continues flowing along the border. After this, the creek turns west-southwest, entering West Chillisquaque Township, before turning south and then west. For more than a mile, the creek flows through a valley between <a href="Montour%20Ridge">Montour Ridge</a> and a smaller hill. Upon leaving the valley, the creek crosses <a href="Pennsylvania%20Route%20147">Pennsylvania Route 147</a> and <a href="Pennsylvania%20Route%20405">Pennsylvania Route 405</a> and heads in a southwesterly direction for several tenths of a mile before reaching its confluence with the West Branch Susquehanna River.
Chillisquaque Creek joins the West Branch Susquehanna River upriver of its mouth.
Tributaries.
Chillisquaque Creek has five named direct tributaries: Beaver Run, Mud Creek, West Branch Chillisquaque Creek, East Branch Chillisquaque Creek, and Middle Branch Chillisquaque Creek. Beaver Run joins Chillisquaque Creek upstream of its mouth and its watershed has an area of . Mud Creek joins Chillisquaque Creek upstream of its mouth and its watershed has an area of . West Branch Chillisquaque Creek joins Chillisquaque Creek upstream of its mouth. East Branch Chillisquaque Creek joins Chillisquaque Creek upstream of its mouth, as does Middle Branch Chillisquaque Creek. Their watersheds have areas of and , respectively.
Hydrology.
Reaches of Chillisquaque Creek are designated as an impaired waterbody. Causes of impairment include <a href="sedimentation">sedimentation</a>/<a href="siltation">siltation</a> and habitat alteration, while likely sources include <a href="agriculture">agriculture</a> and industrial <a href="point%20source%20pollution">point-source discharge</a>. Many streams in the watershed experience significant impacts due to agriculture, as heavy use of agricultural lands reduces the creek's <a href="water%20quality">water quality</a>. A total of of streams, or about 83% of all the stream miles in the watershed, are impaired. The nearby <a href="Mahoning%20Creek%20%28Susquehanna%20River%29">Mahoning Creek</a> is in "better environmental shape" than Chillisquaque Creek. However, in the 1980s, the concentrations of <a href="pollutant">pollutant</a>s in the creek were relatively low, despite being increased by discharges from a nearby <a href="power%20plant">power plant</a>. For instance, the <a href="selenium">selenium</a> concentration was consistently under 0.010 milligrams per liter, the <a href="United%20States%20Environmental%20Protection%20Agency">United States Environmental Protection Agency</a> criterion for that pollutant.
Between 1980 and 2014, the highest average annual <a href="discharge%20%28hydrology%29">discharge</a> of Chillisquaque Creek at Washingtonville was , in 2011. The second-highest average annual discharge, , occurred in 1984, while the third-highest, , occurred in 2004. The lowest average annual discharge, , occurred in 2001. The second-lowest, , occurred in 1988 and the third-lowest, , occurred in 2013. The months with the highest average discharge are March, April, and December; their values are , , and , respectively. The <a href="PPL%20%28utility%29">PPL</a> power plant contributes about of water to the creek.
During several measurements in the 1970s, the <a href="pH">pH</a> of Chillisquaque Creek near Washingtonville ranged from 6.3 to 7.1. The <a href="specific%20conductance">specific conductance</a> of the creek ranged from 170 to 250 <a href="siemens%20%28unit%29">micro-siemens</a> per centimeter at . The <a href="turbidity">turbidity</a> ranged between 2 and 7 <a href="Jackson%20Turbidity%20Unit">Jackson Turbidity Unit</a>s. The concentration of <a href="water%20hardness">water hardness</a> in the creek ranged from 84 to 130 milligrams per liter. The concentration of <a href="dissolved%20oxygen">dissolved oxygen</a> ranged from 9.0 to 11.0 milligrams per liter, while the <a href="hydrogen%20ion">hydrogen ion</a> concentration ranged from 0.00008 to 0.00051 milligrams per liter. The <a href="carbon%20dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> concentration ranged between 4.7 and 49 milligrams per liter.
In the 1970s, the concentration of <a href="nitrate">nitrate</a> as <a href="nitrogen">nitrogen</a> in Chillisquaque Creek near Washingtonville ranged from 1.68 to 2.00 milligrams per liter, while the concentration of <a href="nitrite">nitrite</a> as nitrogen ranged from 0.040 to 0.164 milligrams per liter. The concentration of <a href="phosphorus">phosphorus</a> ranged from 0.040 to 0.520 milligrams per liter. The organic carbon concentration was 3.0 milligrams per liter in one measurement. The concentration of <a href="sulfate">sulfate</a> ranged from 32.0 to 114 milligrams per liter in the creek's filtered water and the <a href="chloride">chloride</a> concentration ranged between 8.0 and 14.0 milligrams per liter, again in filtered water. The <a href="ammonia">ammonia</a> concentration ranged from 0.026 to 0.811 milligrams per liter.
In the 1970s, the concentration of <a href="magnesium">magnesium</a> in Chillisquaque Creek ranged from 1.50 to 9.50 milligrams per liter in the creek's filtered water and the <a href="calcium">calcium</a> concentration ranged from 26.4 to 48.8 milligrams per liter, in filtered water. The <a href="arsenic">arsenic</a> concentration was once measured to be 77 micrograms per liter. The <a href="cadmium">cadmium</a>, recoverable <a href="chromium">chromium</a>, and recoverable <a href="copper">copper</a> concentrations were each once measured to be less than 3, less than 20, and 30 micrograms per liter, respectively. The recoverable <a href="iron">iron</a> concentration ranged from 160 to 410 micrograms per liter. The concentrations of <a href="zinc">zinc</a>, <a href="lead">lead</a>, <a href="manganese">manganese</a>, and <a href="aluminum">aluminum</a> were less than 20, less than 50, 50, and 500 micrograms per liter, respectively. Additionally, a detectable amount of <a href="nickel">nickel</a> was observed in the creek.
Geography, geology, and climate.
The elevation near the <a href="river%20mouth">mouth</a> of Chillisquaque Creek is above <a href="sea%20level">sea level</a>. The elevation of the creek's <a href="river%20source">source</a> is approximately above sea level. The gradient of the creek is about .
The upper reaches of the watershed of Chillisquaque Creek are in the <a href="Muncy%20Hills">Muncy Hills</a>. Montour Ridge is located to the south of the watershed. Additionally, Limestone Ridge is situated near the creek. The creek's drainage basin mainly consists of rolling agricultural land, with some forested <a href="floodplain">floodplain</a>s. Much of the central part of Montour County is in the <a href="100%20year%20flood">100-year</a> floodplain of the creek and its tributaries. In places, it has high, muddy banks, and is generally "placid", save for some <a href="riffle">riffle</a>s and gravel bars. It is rarely blocked by fences and fallen trees, but there are a few strainers. A <a href="Seep%20%28hydrology%29">seep</a> is located along the creek near the Bucknell preserve and a <a href="spring%20%28hydrology%29">spring</a> is located below Pennsylvania Route 54.
The creek is between wide and has no apparent <a href="limestone">limestone</a> influence, despite being near Limestone Ridge and flowing through Limestone Township. 
Chillisquaque Creek flows in a generally southwesterly direction. The <a href="stream%20channel">channel</a> of the creek is <a href="sinuous">sinuous</a> and flows through <a href="rock%20formation">rock formation</a>s consisting of <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a> and <a href="shale">shale</a>. Oriskany sandstone and Lower Helderberg <a href="limestone">limestone</a> occur on Limestone Ridge near it. Oriskany <a href="chert">chert</a>y sandstone occurs near the confluence of the tributary Mud Creek. Additionally, Black Genesee shales have also been observed near the creek, as does the <a href="Tully%20Limestone">Tully limestone</a>. Rock of the <a href="Hamilton%20Group">Hamilton Group</a> is common in the area as well and is in places covered with sandstone boulders of the <a href="Pocono%20Formation">Pocono Formation</a>. <a href="Hydric%20soil">Hydric soil</a>s occur along it in central Montour County.
In the early 1900s, the average annual rate of precipitation in the watershed of Chillisquaque Creek was . The creek has relatively warm water.
Watershed.
The <a href="drainage%20basin">watershed</a> of Chillisquaque Creek has an area of . The mouth of the creek is in the <a href="United%20States%20Geological%20Survey">United States Geological Survey</a> quadrangle of Northumberland. However, its source is in the <a href="quadrangle%20%28geography%29">quadrangle</a> of Washingtonville. The creek also passes through the quadrangle of Milton. The creek can be accessed from Pennsylvania Route 45, Pennsylvania Route 405, and Pennsylvania Route 642.
The watershed of Chillisquaque Creek parts of four counties: Montour County, Northumberland County, <a href="Columbia%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Columbia County</a>, and <a href="Lycoming%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Lycoming County</a>. The portion of Montour County that is in the watershed is the central portion. It is the largest watershed in that county, accounting for 56 percent of its land area. It is also the only large stream in northern Northumberland County. There are about of streams in the watershed.
The land alongside Chillisquaque Creek is mainly used for farming. As of the 1980s, the main crops are <a href="corn">corn</a> and <a href="soybean">soybean</a>s.
There is a <a href="gauging%20station">gauging station</a> on Chillisquaque Creek at Washingtonville. The area of the creek's watershed upstream of this point is . A <a href="reservoir">reservoir</a> known as <a href="Lake%20Chillisquaque">Lake Chillisquaque</a> is located on the tributary Middle Branch Chillisquaque Creek in Anthony Township, Montour County. It is the largest lake/reservoir in Montour County, with an area of . There are two <a href="dam">dam</a>s in the watershed: the Lake Chillisquaque dam and the Montour Ash Basin No 1 dam. Both were built in 1971. The former drains an area of , while the latter drains an area of .
History.
Chillisquaque Creek was entered into the <a href="Geographic%20Names%20Information%20System">Geographic Names Information System</a> on August 2, 1979. Its identifier in the Geographic Names Information System is 1171784. The creek is also known as Chilisquaque Creek. Its name most likely comes from the Shawnee word "chilisuagi", meaning "place of the snow-birds". However, other possible meanings of the word include "flight of the wild goose", "frozen duck", and "man made perfect".
The Shawnee Indians historically had a large village/town at the mouth of Chillisquaque Creek. The village was established by 1728 and was known as Chenastry and Otzinachson. The Shawnees on the creek moved to <a href="Western%20Pennsylvania">Western Pennsylvania</a> in 1728. Additionally, <a href="Andrew%20Montour">Andrew Montour</a> historically owned a <a href="plantations%20in%20the%20American%20South">plantation</a> near the creek's mouth. In 1745, <a href="Bishop%20Spagenberg">Bishop Spagenberg</a> passed by the creek and noted the former Indian village there in his journal. A <a href="Mingo">Mingo</a> chief named <a href="Logan%20%28American%20Indian%20leader%29">Logan</a> was living at the mouth of the creek in about 1753. An elderly couple were scalped by Indians near the creek in 1782.
A frontier fort known as <a href="Fort%20Rice%20%28Pennsylvania%29">Fort Rice</a> used to be located on Chillisquaque Creek near what is now Washingtonville. William Plunket had settled near Chillisquaque Creek as early as 1772. Boyd and Wilson built a <a href="watermill">mill</a> at the mouth of the creek in 1791. The first <a href="Methodist">Methodist</a> <a href="camp%20meeting">camp meeting</a> in the area was held on the creek from the West Branch Susquehanna River in August 1806. The creek was declared a public highway in the 1820s. The <a href="Pennsylvania%20Canal%20%28West%20Branch%20Division%29">West Branch Division</a> of the <a href="Pennsylvania%20Canal">Pennsylvania Canal</a> historically had an aqueduct over the creek. However, by 1842, it was in need of repairs. On July 18 and 19, 1851, a 32-hour-long storm caused Chillisquaque Creek to rise higher than it had in 57 years.
In the early 1900s, the main industries in the creek's watershed included agriculture and <a href="clay">clay</a> mines. The creek was also used as water power for a number of small <a href="watermill">mills</a>. Around this time period, <a href="railroad">railroad</a>s in the watershed included the <a href="Susquehanna%2C%20Bloomsburg%2C%20and%20Berwick%20Railroad">Susquehanna, Bloomsburg, and Berwick Railroad</a> and the <a href="Philadelphia%20and%20Reading%20Railroad">Philadelphia and Reading Railroad</a>. Major communities included Exchange, <a href="Jerseytown%2C%20Pennsylvania">Jerseytown</a>, Potts Grove, Washingtonville, Strawberry Ridge, and White Hall. Their populations were 225, 200, 184, 183, 160, and 140, respectively.
Numerous bridges have been constructed over Chillisquaque Creek in Montour County. A bridge known as the Washingtonville Bridge was built in 1887 and is on the <a href="Historic%20American%20Buildings%20Survey">Historic American Buildings Survey</a>. Another one, which carries Pennsylvania Route 54, was built in 1930. Another bridge was built in 1946 and carries Pennsylvania Route 254 in Washingtonville. A bridge carrying State Route 4008 was built across the creek in 1957 and was repaired in 2010. A bridge carrying State Route 1004 was built across the creek in 1960. Additionally, two bridges carrying Interstate 80 were built over the creek in 1962 and repaired in the late 1990s. A bridge carrying State Route 4004 over the creek was built in 1987 and another bridge carrying Pennsylvania Route 54 was built in 1992. A bridge carrying State Route 1003 was constructed across the creek in 1993 and a bridge carrying State Route 3003 was built over the creek in 1997. In 2005, another bridge carrying State Route 1004 was built over the creek.
A number of bridges have been built over Chillisquaque Creek in Northumberland County as well. One of these was the <a href="Rishel%20Covered%20Bridge">Rishel Covered Bridge</a>, which was built in 1830 and repaired in 1990. It is listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>. The <a href="Gottlieb%20Brown%20Covered%20Bridge">Gottlieb Brown Covered Bridge</a>, which carries T594, was built across the creek in 1881 and was repaired in 1985. It is also on the National Register of Historic Places. A bridge carrying State Route 1025 was constructed over the creek in 1926 and a bridge carrying Pennsylvania Route 45 was built over the creek in 1952. A three-span bridge carrying Pennsylvania Route 642 was built over the creek in 1958 and was repaired in 2012. A two-span bridge carrying Pennsylvania Route 405 was built over the creek in 1974.
A number of studies and inventories have been carried out on Chillisquaque Creek. Such studies include Pennsylvania's 208 Study in 1979, an assessment by the <a href="Pennsylvania%20Department%20of%20Environmental%20Protection">Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection</a>, and an assessment by Bucknell University in 2003.
Biology.
The drainage basin of Chillisquaque Creek is designated as a Warmwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery. The creek was observed by A. Joseph Armstrong to lack <a href="trout">trout</a>. In 1986, the creek was not being <a href="fish%20stocking">stocked</a>. However, it was stocked with <a href="black%20bass">black bass</a>, <a href="Centrarchidae">sunfish</a>, and <a href="yellow%20perch">yellow perch</a> in 1934 and with <a href="yellow%20perch">yellow perch</a> in the spring of 1936. In 1986, it contained many of the species found in the West Branch Susquehanna River, including <a href="rock%20bass">rock bass</a>. <a href="Smallmouth%20bass">Smallmouth bass</a> have also been observed in the creek. Disease is moderately common among young-of-the-year smallmouth bass in the creek. 2011 was the first year where diseased smallmouth bass were documented in the creek since studies began in 2009.
A tract of forested <a href="floodplain">floodplain</a> known as the Chillisquaque Creek Natural Area (or Bucknell Preserve, Tobias Marsh, or Mexico Road Swamp) is located in Liberty Township, Montour County. A <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a> bottomland forest with pools and channels occurs along the creek, while more <a href="mesic%20forest">mesic forest</a>s occur higher up. The tract of land is owned by <a href="Bucknell%20University">Bucknell University</a>, whose students and faculty sometimes conduct research there. The tract has an area of and has a high level of tree <a href="biodiversity">biodiversity</a>. Common tree species include <a href="basswood">basswood</a>, <a href="bitternut%20hickory">bitternut hickory</a>, <a href="pin%20oak">pin oak</a>, and <a href="shagbark%20hickory">shagbark hickory</a>. In the preserve, there is also a population of <a href="cat-tail%20sedge">cat-tail sedge</a>s. <a href="Graminoid">Graminoid</a> marshes occur along the creek near Mexico Road. Such marshes are mainly dominated by <a href="cattail">cattail</a>s, grasses, <a href="rush%20%28plant%29">rushes</a>, and <a href="sedge">sedge</a>s.
Reaches of Chillisquaque Creek in Derry Township, Montour County would benefit from additional <a href="riparian%20buffer">riparian buffer</a>ing consisting of <a href="native%20species">native</a> trees to mitigate the effects of <a href="nonpoint%20source%20pollution">nonpoint source pollution</a>. Woodland <a href="wildflower">wildflower</a>s such as <a href="Mertensia">bluebells</a> occur along the creek in April. <a href="Virginia%20cowslip">Virginia cowslip</a>s, <a href="Mentha">mint</a>, <a href="Symplocarpus%20foetidus">skunk cabbage</a>, <a href="mountain%20honeysuckle">mountain honeysuckle</a>, and <a href="scallion">scallion</a>s also are common along it towards the end of April.
A number of bird species occur at the Bucknell Preserve along Chillisquaque Creek. These include <a href="marsh%20wren">marsh wren</a>s and <a href="Sora%20%28bird%29">soras</a>. <a href="Virginia%20rail">Virginia rail</a>s were observed at the site in 1980 and 1984, though it is likely that they still remain there. Additionally, several <a href="mussel">mussel</a> species that require high levels of <a href="water%20quality">water quality</a> to survive have been observed in the creek. In the Montour County reach of the watershed of Chillisquaque Creek, <a href="livestock">livestock</a> is commonly allowed access to streams.
Recreation.
At least of Chillisquaque Creek, from <a href="Pennsylvania%20Route%2054">Pennsylvania Route 54</a> at Washingtonville downstream to its mouth, are navigable by <a href="canoe">canoe</a>. The difficulty rating of the creek is 1 and the scenery is described in Edward Gertler's book "Keystone Canoeing" as "good". The creek is suitable for beginners and is typically canoeable from March to May, with the exception of dry years. Not much water is required to canoe on it. However, there is no access to the creek's mouth.
A <a href="greenway%20%28landscape%29">greenway</a> corridor for Chillisquaque Creek was proposed in the Montour County Comprehensive Plan. Fishing and boating are permitted on Lake Chillisquaque, though only non-powered and electric boats are allowed. The best fishing opportunities on the creek are in the springtime. However, A. Joseph Armstrong's book "Trout Unlimited's Guide to Pennsylvania Limestone Streams" described the creek as "not an attractive stream.".
A campsite known as Shangri-La on the Creek is situated on Chillisquaque Creek at the base of Montour Ridge. It has 52 creekside sites and another 115 sites that are forested to varying degrees. Recreational opportunities at the site include <a href="fishing">fishing</a> and <a href="Frisbee%20golf">Frisbee golf</a>.
A reach of Chillisquaque Creek was once a third-priority candidate for a <a href="Pennsylvania%20Scenic%20Rivers">Pennsylvania Scenic Rivers</a> designation.
